contentrichtext.text: {{Press release|date=May 2009}} {{Infobox Album <!--See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Albums --> | Name = Night and Day II | Type = studio | Artist = [[Joe Jackson (musician)|Joe Jackson]] | Cover = JoeJacksonNightAndDay2.jpg | Released = October 24, 2000 | Recorded = | Genre = [[Rock music|Rock]] | Length = | Label = [[Sony Classical]] | Producer = [[Joe Jackson (musician)|Joe Jackson]] | Last album = ''[[Summer in the City: Live in New York]]''<br />(2000) | This album = '''''Night and Day II'''''<br />(2000) | Next album = ''[[Two Rainy Nights]]''<br />(2002) }} {{Album reviews |rev1 = [[Allmusic]] |rev1score = {{Rating|3|5}}<ref>[{{Allmusic|class=album|id=r503856|pure_url=yes}} Allmusic review]</ref> }}<!-- Automatically generated by DASHBot--> '''''Night and Day II''''' is a 2000 [[album]] by [[Joe Jackson (musician)|Joe Jackson]]. It was a revisit of the style of a prior album, ''[[Night and Day (Joe Jackson album)|Night and Day]]''. The songs are about [[New York City|New York]] lifestyle, seen by different characters. It featured a new set of songs in the spirit of his most popular previous recording.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |first= |last= |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p4574/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Biography by William Ruhlmann |publisher=Allmusic.com |accessdate=4 May 2009}}</ref> While the original ''Night and Day'' (1982) took a satirical look at the downfalls of city life via songs like "TV Age", "Cancer" and "Real Men", ''Night and Day II'' is a commentary that steps into the dark side of inner city living as seen though the eyes of a cynical New Yorker (Jackson lived in New York at the time) and seemingly never glances up to seek a lighter tone. "Hell of a Town" and "Stranger Than You" (the featured song of the album) display a biting sarcasm of New York City life, along with [[lyrics]] from songs like "Just Because": <blockquote> ''My hovel needs a barricade''<br /> ''My pants need an alarm''<br /> ''Need some non-alcoholic whiskey''<br /> ''and some Giuliani charm'' </blockquote> making a commentary on [[Rudy Giuliani]]'s mayoralty. This reflection of the original ''Night and Day'' album can be seen in many forms: from the cover (the artwork from 1982's ''Night and Day'' features a white background while the photograph from 2000's ''Night and Day II'' is a dark nighttime shot taken from within a New York City cab, and shows the World Trade Center just a year before 9/11), to the perceived presentation order of each song's motif — ''Night and Day'' feels as if the listener is being taken on a journey, via the song motifs, from daytime to night while ''Night and Day II'' presents a sensation of moving from nighttime to day ("Glamour and Pain" to "Love Got Lost" demonstrates this fully as "Glamour and Pain" deals with a prostitute's lamentations while "Love Got Lost" is mostly placed during [[Marianne Faithfull]]'s fictitious working day). The final song of the album, "Stay", might seem to be somewhat disconcerting upon reflection — Jackson left New York to return to England in 2003. The music is built with contributions from [[Graham Maby]] ([[bass guitar|bass]]), and Sue Hadjopoulos ([[percussion instrument|percussion]]). Also featured are the [[string instrument|string]] [[quartet]] [[Ethel (string quartet)|Ethel]], and three guest vocalists: [[Iran]]ian diva [[Sussan Deyhim]], [[Drag (clothing)|drag]] performer Dale De Vere and Baroness "Sacher-Masoch" Marianne Faithfull, who sings vocals on "Love Got Lost". == Track listing == All songs written, arranged, produced and sung by Joe Jackson, unless otherwise noted. # "Prelude" - 1:57 # "Hell of a Town" - 3:18 # "Stranger Than You" - 4:16 # "Why" <small>(vocals by Sussan Deyhim)</small> - 3:54 # "Glamour and Pain" <small>(vocals by Dale De Vere)</small> - 5:59 # "Dear Mom" - 4:12 # "Love Got Lost" <small>(vocals by Marianne Faithfull, Joe Jackson and Alexandra Montano)</small> - 6:59 # "Just Because..." - 4:45 # "Happyland" - 5:12 # "Stay" - 5:46 == References == {{reflist}} {{Joe Jackson}} [[Category:2001 albums]] [[Category:Joe Jackson (musician) albums]]
